text: Our friends at The Meaning Movement created this great cheatsheet for improving your LinkedIn profile. It's free and a great resource for your career. Enjoy!

Hi everyone! Welcome to r/work! Here are a couple things to keep in mind when posting:  
**1) Karma -** There is a minimum karma requirement for posting in order to prevent spam. If you've never posted to Reddit before, you're going to need to interact and gain some karma before posting here.  
**2) Content and engagement** - This community prefers dialogue, questions, and engagement. Don't post here just to get clicks on your YouTube channel or whatever. If you're looking for work memes, check out /r/workmemes/.

So I started working this part-time job almost two months ago and I've noticed that people get a little offended/annoyed when you don't share details about your personal life. 

Personally, I've always tried separating my personal life with work. I don't want my coworkers knowing anything about me personally, except if I develop an affinity for someone. 

In this job specifically, I've noticed that a portion of the other coworkers share EVERYTHING with each other (marital problems, kid issues, etc). Personally, I haven't shared anything personal about me except for very standard things (such as what I study, etc.), but I feel the rest don't really like that. 

Is this something that's commonly experienced in workplaces?

I started a new job recently. I asked for $55K starting salary as the minimum. They only offered me $50K and said that was the max they could do (I took it because I had no other offers, but was not happy with that salary).

2 weeks later and I get another job offer. This one is 100% remote (the other position I accepted was in person and a 40 minute commute each way). And this one offered me $70K to start. Of course I took it!

When I let my boss know I was leaving for the other job, after only two weeks working there, she starts saying "Well I would like to retain you, I can see if I can get approval for a $55K salary for you. I laughed and explained what I was offered ($20K more & remote) and that I know it would be impossible for them to offer me that. She said, you're right, we can't match that. Then she gets all upset and starts lecturing me about how they invested so much time and training into me and now I'm leaving them in a bind.

A month later I see her stalking my LinkedIn profile (because I didn't mention the new company name when I quit).

Lol can you believe the nerve of these people? Absolutely clueless!

I have my annual review tomorrow. This is my first job after graduating college and I have had a rough start, which I believe is just due to a learning curve and it being my first job. I tend to get anxious sometimes, and then it results in my crying even if I don‚Äôt want to cry. I‚Äôm wondering if anyone else experiences this and maybe has any advice to prevent this from happening tomorrow. This isn‚Äôt my first review with them as I started around the time of annual review time last year but have recently become more anxious at work.

I‚Äôm 21F and I work at my school's cafeteria as a cashier. My coworker has some personal issues that affect their work attendance, and I often have to cover for them when they leave early or don't show up. I find myself constantly adjusting my tasks to accommodate their needs, which can be challenging. While I understand and sympathize with their situation, I sometimes feel overwhelmed by the extra workload. Despite this, we have a good relationship, and I appreciate the help they have given me outside of work. I can't help but feel conflicted about my feelings of frustration in this situation.

Curious to hear how people in advertising or media are actually using AI tools to their advantage. Not the generic "it'll replace creatives" conversation, but the real, practical stuff. And not using it to help draft emails or LinkedIn posts.

I've been experimenting with a few things myself (mostly for help concepting and story-boarding) but I'm still trying to figure out what's genuinely useful long-term vs. just quick hit, on-the-spot help.

If you work in creative, strategy, or media, I'd love to hear what parts of your workflow AI has improved? And when is it really not worth spending the extra time creating a prompt to train AI for?

I‚Äôm the only person at my job that has a good attitude, that does every task without being asked, and if you do ask i almost always already did it. i know every station, i know how to train new people, i know how to help. everyone else just sits on their behind and makes the same dollar i do. and i know ‚Äúwhy bust your behind if you don‚Äôt have to‚Äù. but not only does my shift goes by faster when i work my hardest,  im not gonna stoop lower just because everyone around me does. but it‚Äôs definitely taken a mental toll on me always being the one to cover shifts and being asked to do hardest tasks that everyone‚Äôs too lazy to help with. i just struggle because this job makes me enough money (emphasis on the enough) and it‚Äôs the only place i can work at this wage to keep myself afloat in my area. has anyone gone through similar feelings or experiences?

I really dislike this time of year when we're asked to make goals for the next year. I just want to keep doing what I'm doing. I'm not looking to move up...I just want to do my job. After a while, there is only so much a person can list as a goal...or 3 to 5 goals. And I work remote so I can't have any goals that require in-person activities.

Every year, I have no idea what to even put, and it doesn't help that I wait until the last possible moment to get this done! üò≠

Okay, long story short, I was working Wednesdays through Sundays every week for over a year. I got tired of never having a single day of the weekend to myself. I tried to request Sundays off, but my manager refused. I went above her head and spoke to the GM, who approved my request. In retaliation, my manager cut my Fridays in addition to Sundays, leaving me with only 2-3 days a week. She also gossiped about everyone behind their backs. I contacted HR, who advised me to talk to the GM. The GM promised to try to get me hours at another store, but nothing came of it. Eventually, my manager had to give me my Fridays back because she couldn't find anyone else to work. 

Recently, she told me I had to work either Christmas or Thanksgiving. We had the same argument last year, and I refused to miss time with my family for minimum wage. In response, she cut my hours again to 2-3 days a week. My friends and coworkers believe this is clear retaliation and suggest suing the company. I'm unsure about the payout for a retaliation lawsuit or if it's worth pursuing. Should I contact HR again for guidance? Any help in navigating this situation would be appreciated.

I'm a VP of a small software company, and we have a new CEO. He's very focused on connecting with C-level executives at our clients, and insists that my team should mainly interact with C-level members. He mentioned that "Anything less than Director is not valuable."

Given that we work with global companies, meeting with these executives is extremely challenging.

However, I also interact with our vendors, and I've been providing the CEO's contact information, suggesting that he enjoys direct connections with our vendor partners.

This approach has resulted in three calls this week, and he is becoming frustrated.

This keeps happening to me at work and I honestly don‚Äôt know the right way to handle it.

I‚Äôll start sharing an idea in a meeting, and before I can finish, someone jumps in ‚Äî sometimes to ‚Äúadd‚Äù to what I‚Äôm saying, sometimes to change the topic entirely.  
It happens so fast that I just‚Ä¶ stop talking.

Then I sit there feeling invisible while the conversation moves on, and all I can think is how small I must have looked.

Afterward, I get frustrated with myself for not speaking up ‚Äî I imagine myself saying something confident like,

But in real life, I just freeze and smile politely.

I know they‚Äôre probably not doing it maliciously, but it still hurts.

How do you handle it in the moment without sounding defensive or awkward?  
And how do you rebuild confidence when it starts to feel like your voice doesn‚Äôt matter in the room?

So, apparently people at my job have been gossiping recently. My boss sent out an email saying that if anyone gossips they get written up. However, my boss also said that even if the gossiping occurs outside of work you could get written up. That doesn‚Äôt seem right to me. Can she really write someone up if they met up with a coworker outside of work and gossiped?

Hey all,

This is my first post in this sub, I‚Äôm looking for some validation and advice on how to handle my current situation at work.

Basically, I have a difficult coworker at my job, a woman in her mid 40s who I will be referring to as Shannon. At first, we got along well, she came off as very bubbly and charismatic, and we were able to have good conversations. Then, not long after she must‚Äôve decided that she didn‚Äôt like the way things were run around here. She took particular issue with the way in which the other campus aides and I bring the trash barrels around to each table near the end of each lunch period. We ask students to pass down trash so that the tables are clear for the custodians to clean afterwards. Shannon decided that this was ‚Äúspoiling‚Äù the kids, and multiple times I‚Äôve gotten snide comments. She doesn‚Äôt push barrels herself but even will confront students who have trash and make them get up in an aggressive manner.

Overall, it‚Äôs become increasingly challenging to coexist with her, as she is clearly not my boss and has no authority to boss me around, but for some reason feels like she has the right to give me directions and has been difficult across the board. I‚Äôm not a very confrontational‚Äîor even assertive‚Äîperson, but it‚Äôs gotten to the point where I can no longer brush off her constant pokes. So I‚Äôm looking for professional ways to say ‚Äúthat‚Äôs not my job‚Äù, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre not in charge‚Äù, or anything along those lines that doesn‚Äôt seem unnecessarily incendiary but still sends the clear message to stay in her lane and stop expecting things to change because she wants them to.

Any advice?

Little backstory: I work at my college's on-campus coffee shop. I have been here for a year and a half and I enjoy working with my coworkers. However, my boss has been a problem. I had to take a break during the summer due to personal reasons, and when I returned, my boss started making inappropriate jokes about my situation. Today, it crossed a line when he called me a brat in front of my coworkers, referring to what happened over the summer. He shared personal details about my situation without my consent.

I am unsure about how to handle this situation. I value my job but I also don't want to tolerate this behavior. Should I consider reporting my boss? I am concerned about potential repercussions. Am I overreacting?

My company was recently acquired, leading to changes in travel booking procedures. Previously, I was issued a business credit card to cover expenses. Now, the new company is transitioning to Concur for travel booking and expects us to pay for meals, transportation, gas, parking, etc., and will reimburse us biweekly. Given my frequent travel to multiple cities each week, expenses can quickly add up to $200-300 due to airport parking, gas, and meals. Do you think my concerns are valid or am I overreacting?

The person who contacted me (recruiter) isn't the person who interviewed me, the team manager did. I don't have the manager's name, I only have the recruiter's email. How can I send a thank you note for them both?

I genuinely don't know if I'm being unreasonable or getting played.

My manager left in March. I was told "we're restructuring, can you handle the team temporarily?" I said yes because I thought it would be 4-6 weeks and would look good for a promotion.

It's now November. I'm doing the full job. 1-on-1s, performance reviews, hiring decisions, budget planning, the works. My title is still "Senior" and my pay hasn't changed.

What I've been told:

* "We're waiting for headcount approval" (3 months ago)
* "The promotion is in process" (2 months ago)
* "Just need to finalize the new org structure" (last month)
* "You're doing great, we really appreciate your flexibility" (every week)

I'm getting manager responsibilities with IC pay. My team thinks I'm their manager. Other departments treat me like a manager. I'm in manager meetings. But when it comes to title and compensation? "Still in process."

I keep being nice about it. Every time my boss says "thanks for being patient," I smile and say "no problem, happy to help." But internally I'm screaming because I've been patient for 8 months and I'm literally doing a job I'm not being paid for.

At what point do I stop being the "team player" and start being the person who says "pay me for the job I'm doing or give it to someone else"?

Because right now I feel like I'm teaching them that they can get manager-level work for senior IC money, and once you teach someone that, why would they ever change it?

Has anyone been in this position? How did you handle it without torching your reputation? Or did you just eat it and move on?

I'm genuinely torn between "this is how you get ahead, prove yourself first" and "this is how you get exploited, demand what you're worth."

What would you do?

I just put my PTO for December, and our HR person responded with: 

"Congratulations for using all of your PTO! By using all of your time, it demonstrates that you value yourself, your family and friends, and the importance of time away from work to recharge and refocus. Taking your full-time off helps sustain productivity, creativity, and overall wellness, precisely the qualities we should carry over into the new year."

We only have 10 PTO days and they don't roll over to the next year. This is strange to congratulate!

Thanks in advance to this sub for letting me rant. I am open to any recommendations. 6 months ago I changed careers, it's been a rather steep learning curve, but about 2 weeks ago things began to click. My partner and I are the only people in our department. He is very experienced and while he is my peer, he has been instrumental in teaching me everything about the job. This was by design, and overall it's worked out very well. As I said, about 2 weeks ago I started getting the hang of things. We prepared for him to go on vacation and I wasn't worried. I had a good handle on things that needed to be taken care of while he was away and I have other resources available. Cut to the chase, we got some emails yesterday that needed thoughtful and detailed responses. I drafted them before the end of the day and my plan was to send them first thing this am after a read through to be sure I'm on point. I fire up my email to find that he responded to these message and also sent me messages about other things that I already was aware of. I am angry because this was a huge opportunity for me to show the skills that I've learned. Not only that, it seems to reinforce that I don't know what I'm doing because his out of office message indicates that he had no access to email and would not be responding to messages. End rant. Recommendations ( other than ripping him a new one via email). Thank you in advance fellow workers.

Something I've noticed is that recruiters will email you, ask you for your availability in which I respond the same then they ghost me. I don't get it, why would you reach to me in the first place. This happened to me and a few of my friends looking for work.

Anyone else experiencing something similar or is it just me?

So, my boss asked me to be in charge of overseeing the phone refresh project. The goal is to upgrade users with Iphone 12's to newer models. There are multiple tickets assigned to my team members, but none to me.

Since I lack the authority to assign tasks, I decided to offer to handle tech problem tickets in exchange for team members focusing on scheduling the phone swaps. I also took the initiative to message users directly via Teams, scheduling follow-up messages to remind them to reach out to techs for their tickets.

My next step is to follow up with both users and techs to ensure the scheduling is done. Additionally, I plan to send a weekly progress email to my boss, with whom I have limited communication.

To increase the chances of success, I could consider adding regular check-ins with team members to track progress and address any issues promptly.

I really dislike this time of year when we're asked to make goals for the next year. I just want to keep doing what I'm doing. I'm not looking to move up...I just want to do my job. After a while, there is only so much a person can list as a goal...or 3 to 5 goals. And I work remote so I can't have any goals that require in-person activities.

Every year, I have no idea what to even put, and it doesn't help that I wait until the last possible moment to get this done! üò≠

Going back to work in person soon! I know it can get difficult to balance because it feels like the entire day is gone and you feel tired and don‚Äôt want to do anything after work during the week. I‚Äôd like to include gym after work. Also, anyone recommend a service for midday dog walking?

I'm looking for recommendations for an executive coach/speaker to give a maybe 2-4 hour workshop on avoiding micromanaging for a group of managers and staff. Stuff like being aware of what it looks like, how it affects morale, and tips to avoid it. Maybe some stuff on 'managing up' for staff looking for ways to address it either directly or through personal processes. 

Someone who is able to be in person in Southern Ontario Canada, though potentially online could work.

I know I can google it but I find recommendations to be more indicative of value particularly in the world of coaching.

So I‚Äôve been working full-time for almost 3 months now. I used to be an intern in one team, then got promoted ‚Äî but to a totally different team. At first I was really excited, but honestly‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt think I like what I‚Äôm doing. It‚Äôs not even that I don‚Äôt want to care ‚Äî I‚Äôm trying. I show up, I take notes, I ask questions. But I still have no idea what‚Äôs going on half the time. People talk about projects and numbers like everyone‚Äôs on the same page, and I just sit there thinking ‚Äúwhat the heck are we even talking about.‚Äù I‚Äôm more of a creative person, while this work is purely analytical. I feel like I‚Äôm not dumb, but this job makes me feel dumb. The topics don‚Äôt click, and I just don‚Äôt find them interesting. Which makes it even harder to focus or learn. Now one of the executives is going on parental leave soon and I‚Äôm supposed to take over some of his stuff‚Ä¶ which freaks me out because I barely understand my own tasks. Part of me wants to push through and do well ‚Äî like, I want people to say ‚Äúshe really stepped up while he was gone.‚Äù But another part of me is just‚Ä¶ done. Has anyone been in a job like this? How do you stay motivated when you honestly don‚Äôt care about the work? I don‚Äôt want to quit (at least not yet), I just need to survive this stage without losing my mind.

My boss occasionally forgets to file our payroll on time, causing a one-day delay. Today, I didn't receive my pay and when I asked, she mentioned it was due to a federal holiday (Veterans Day) yesterday. However, today is not a holiday, and she usually files payroll on Mondays. I researched and found that if payday falls on a holiday, there might be a delay, but it shouldn't apply today. I'm unsure if this delay is legal or normal due to the holiday.

I am an office administrator for a small contractor that I have been working for over 7 years. Other than the owner and his wife, I have been the only technical employee for the last 2 years. We sub out all of the work. Well, our main sub is also a general contractor and the owner of the company I am working for is wanting to sell to him supposedly by the end of the year. However, my boss hasn't been here for quite a long time other than to pick up mail. He is selling his house and did also tell me that he is wanting to be done by the end of the year. The guy my boss is selling to told me he spoke to him and my boss said he was on his way to his boat, to go sailing to the Bahamas for 6 months!

He thought he had everything figured out I guess, but it is not that simple. Anyway, my job isn't to make sure he is taking care of stuff. My job is to be the office administrator. Things have been slower lately so lately I find myself just doing what NEEDS to be done. I've had a rough morning with my kindergartner not wanting to go to school and hanging on to me. It's been a rough morning. My mom found out yesterday she has cancer. On the bright side of that it is Stage zero and seems she may not need chemo and possibly not even radiation. It's hard to talk to her about anything. I would just rather speak about my situation to a bunch of strangers, it's like therapy.

I have lots of flexibility, my son was suspended for 5 days and for 4 of them I had him here with me at the office. I feel like I take advantage, but in my defense I haven't gotten a raise in 2 1/2 years.

1. Having to come up with a business and development goal every 6 months can be challenging. They require 3 of each and when you feel stumped on what to say, it can be frustrating.

2. Getting rushed multiple times a day is annoying. There always seems to be a man (so far it ALWAYS is) treading behind you so fast and loud right over your shoulder. It can feel like they are being intentionally disruptive.

3. Coworkers being obsessed with what you have for lunch can be tiresome. Lunch should be a time to decompress, not to be interrogated about your food choices.

4. Never having a moment of peace in the bathroom can be frustrating. It seems like all the bathrooms in the building are always occupied when you need a moment of privacy.

I (23f) have been working full time for little over a year now as a materials engineer. I do not really care for my job, I don't love it but I don't dislike it either. Benefits are good, very well paid for a junior I think, everyone is incredibly nice, very understanding boss. Nonetheless, I leave my house at 7 am and get back somewhere between 17:30-18:00. By the time I get home, I have about 4-5 hours to myself, one of which I always reserve for an active-participation hobby like playing piano, sports, or language learning. During the autumn/winter months, I feel like I barely see the sun, and my friends' schedules never line up. I get up, go to work, come back, get ready for the next day, sleep, repeat. How do people go decades dedicating 90% of their awake time to their job, whether they like it or not, and not lose all motivation in life?

I was recently promoted to a supervisor in October and have been with the company for about 2 years. Today, I was asked for a meeting with HR, but my direct boss was not included, which is unusual. I had a recent issue with my direct deposit due to my promotion, but it was resolved. Now, I am invited to a meeting with HR and another colleague to discuss a concern that was brought to their attention. I am unsure about the purpose of the meeting, but I am staying positive and open-minded.
I'm trying to use AI to create a completely passive income of around $3000-$10000 a month.

The owner of the company where I work is suddenly changing people from the positions they've had for years, moving them to different offices, sometimes moving them to completely different fields, demoting them, and only keeping the ones who work diligently. Basically he's firing anyone who has been acting their wage, which is the minimum wage, and bringing around 60 workers from Asia. That's not counting that everyone here is salaried and don't get the legal benefits they should stated by the law. I'm already applying to other jobs and taking it easy, because after being demoted from the job that actually interested me and having the owner tell me on my face that the workers are not good enough, I'm internally laughing and applying.

Multitasking sounds efficient, but I‚Äôve come to think it‚Äôs one of the biggest hidden drains on creativity. Every switch between tasks costs focus, and the residue from one decision often clouds the next. It‚Äôs like carrying mental baggage between meetings.

Lately, I‚Äôve been exploring ways to simplify work routines by segmenting focus time more intentionally. I noticed that reflective tools encourage structured thinking rather than endless task juggling. It‚Äôs not just about tracking work but improving the quality of thought behind it.

How do you deal with the pressure to stay ‚Äúproductive‚Äù while keeping your head clear? Is multitasking something you actively avoid or try to master?
genuine question. Do not think its burn out. I'm ready to work but the work isn't exciting.

Didn‚Äôt expect to feel this sentimental today but man‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm lucky to do what I do. I get to help veterans and their families every day, people who‚Äôve already given more than most of us ever will. Hearing their stories is so humbling. I used to think work was just about numbers and paychecks and was so focused on that, but it‚Äôs not. It‚Äôs about purpose and serving vets and their families. So yeah‚Ä¶ shoutout to all the vets out there today. You‚Äôve done so much for all of us, and I‚Äôm just grateful I get to help in some small way.

How can I cope with this? Huge line out the door, then my job requires so much bureaucracy and paperwork for certain transactions...and I'm new, so mostly some of it I still don't get! I feel overwhelmed right now but I need this job, I'm on my last savings!
Because apparently, we needed 12 people and 45 minutes to read one bullet point.

I work a niche position in a large insurance company HQ. My job is mostly physical/hands-on so I‚Äôm here during normal business hours. The busyness ebbs and flows as I‚Äôm largely on-call. 

But there's often hours of downtime daily between tasks. I like to stay busy. Have asked for (and received, and completed) additional tasks from other departments. There‚Äôs just nothing right now, but I can‚Äôt leave or work remotely. 

I really like my company and coworkers, I‚Äôm regarded highly and I‚Äôm great at my job. My superiors think I walk on water and largely leave me alone. Honestly I‚Äôm very lucky I have little to complain about! But I genuinely feel bad for doomscrolling on the clock.

Anyone else with similar on-call type jobs feel this? What do you do with your time?

Does anyone work in an environment where people judge you for taking a one day off instead of a 2-week holiday? 

It‚Äôs so weird. I work most of the year and I don‚Äôt take multiple weeks off so that I‚Äôm here to answer everyone but people seem to get annoyed. 

Anyone experience that at all?

Lately, I‚Äôve been struggling to keep up with work. I used to average around 30 hours a week, and back then I thought I was underworking. Now, I can barely push myself past 15. I‚Äôm a game developer and a freelancer, and my motivation has just faded, and I also work remotely.

But this feels deeper like I‚Äôve lost the drive that used to fuel me. Maybe it‚Äôs just exhaustion, or maybe it‚Äôs the isolation of freelancing. No team, no feedback loop, no real sense of progress or purpose. I remember being excited to try new things, build stuff, work on my ideas, but I just don't want to do anything anymore these days.

Just needed advice, is there anything you did that made work meaningful again?

I wanna preface this by saying that from the culture where I am come from respect for your superiors and elders it's very engrained, and it's hard for me to part from that. I am also an extremely empathetic person, and guilty of absorbing people's feelings at times.

My supervisor wasn't necessarily a good person or a supervisor, but they weren't a monster. They had many faults but this situation feels like it's designed to humiliate them. They are now technically my peer, but in the few days they have been demoted, they have been chewed up for asking for help with the workload. We have been asked to delete them from email chains. It's like their existence makes management upset.

I don't like to see them like this, it feels like if they had that many failures it would have been more humane to let them go. I don't know how to approach them for tasks because I cannot talk to them like I talk to the other people on my area. It's uncomfortable. It's sad.

I guess basically, I need advice on how to overcome this situation. Should I offer support? Should I avoid interactions so I don't feel uncomfortable? Should I pray they decide to leave?

They all go the same- not just for me but for others I‚Äôve known as well. They all start off great, you feel comfortable and satisfied with the environment and it all feels too good to be true. Usually because it is. Give it a month or two and it always ends up being drama, unnecessary pressure, and the weird feeling of a hierarchy over your head you have no control over. Especially if it‚Äôs a new store.

I could go on and on about this as I‚Äôve worked 3 in between my retail jobs and they all go like this. What are your experiences with working family-owned businesses and do you agree?

I‚Äôm in the middle of another one of these situations and I feel like I'm losing my mind all over again. I‚Äôm looking for an out ASAP because the drama has just started- which is a shame because once again it is the management and not the job that makes me want to leave. I love my coworkers and even the lead of the new location I‚Äôm at who is related to the owners, it‚Äôs really just the owners themselves that make it miserable.

Hi everyone,

I am in a dilemma. I have been working at my current job for about 2 years. The job involves visiting customers in a mobile office setting, which requires me to drive at least 60 minutes one way. I am provided with a company car and gas, including some for personal use. On office days, I still have to drive 60 minutes one way, with remote work available one day every other week. Lately, this commute has started to bother me. Despite having a good salary and other benefits, my old company reached out to me a week ago, offering a slightly higher salary and the same benefits, but with the office located 15-20 minutes away.

I am considering going back to my old company. What do you think?

Over the years of being FF/EMT-B I've seen and heard of some ridiculous complaints and attempted write-ups.

The dumbest complaint I ever received was from a rich girl who was the definition of Daddy's Money. She complained to my boss at the ambulance. We were transporting her grandmother to a doctor's appointment, and she mentioned she's going to Hawaii the next week. I mentioned to her that I've been to Hawaii and it's nice. She actually complained to the boss because I've been to Hawaii. From what I was told, she was trying to say it's for people like her and not me, a lowly blue-collar worker. My boss told her we're not transporting her grandmother anymore. He was fed up with her and her complaints.

The dumbest write-up someone tried to give me was from a lieutenant who was rude to begin with. It's a tie between two that he tried to give.

The first one was when my girlfriend came by the station, and I gave her some money to pay a bill for me. I gave her a kiss goodbye. The next day, I got called into the office, and he was demanding I get written up or fired for soliciting prostitution.

The second incident was when he wanted me fired because "all veterans have PTSD" and according to him, he was scared for his life.

Both attempts were rejected, and I went about my day.

Strolling away from workstations could prove costly for some employees at a technology services company, as the company explores tracking productivity through mouse and keyboard movement.

About a month ago, the firm rolled out a course for executives to familiarize them with workforce-management tools such as ProHance, as part of select projects, becoming arguably the latest to double down on micro-tracking employee activities.

An employee will be marked ‚Äúidle if no keyboard or mouse activity is detected for more than 300 seconds," according to the course.

Just received an email from the senior manager requesting a discussion about my role, with HR and my manager present. It seems like a typical redundancy setup, but there's a concerning pattern emerging. Over the past month, they have been meticulously documenting minor issues, leading to a shift in my performance evaluations from "meeting expectations" to "concerns about output." Despite no actual changes in my work quality, the framing has shifted.
